sentences.sentence: It is for that purpose, again, that I have bought a box of paints and some pencils.
It is hard to take up drawing again at my age,
when I have never made any pictures except those of the boa constrictor( 大蟒蛇 ) from the outside and the boa constrictor( 大蟒蛇 ) from the inside, since I was six.
I shall certainly try to make my portraits( 肖像画 ) as true to life as possible.
But I am not at all sure of success.
One drawing goes along all right, and another has no resemblance( 相似 ) to its subject.
I make some errors, too, in the little prince’s height: in one place he is too tall and in another too short.
And I feel some doubts about the color of his costume( 服装 ).
So I fumble( 摸索 ) along as best I can, not good, not bad, and I hope generally fair-to-middling( 马马虎虎 ).
In certain more important details( 细节 ) I shall make mistakes, also.
But that is something that will not be my fault.
My friend never explained anything to me.
He thought, perhaps, that I was like himself.
But I, alas( 唉 ), do not know how to see sheep through the walls of boxes.
Perhaps I am a little like the grown-ups( 成年人 ).
I have had to grow old.
As each day passed I would learn, in our talk, something about the little prince’s planet, his departure( 离去 ) from it, his journey.
The information would come very slowly, as it might chance to fall from his thoughts.
It was in this way that I heard, on the third day, about the catastrophe( 大灾难 ) of the baobabs( 猴面包树 ).
This time, once more, I had the sheep to thank for it.
For the little prince asked me abruptly( 突然地 )—as if seized by a grave( 严肃的 ) doubt—“It is true, isn’t it, that sheep eat little bushes?”
“Yes, that is true.”
“Ah! I am glad!”
I did not understand why it was so important that sheep should eat little bushes.
But the little prince added:
“Then it follows that they also eat baobabs( 猴面包树 )?”
I pointed out to the little prince that baobabs( 猴面包树 ) were not little bushes, but, on the contrary, trees as big as castles;
and that even if he took a whole herd( 兽群 ) of elephants away with him, the herd( 兽群 ) would not eat up one single baobab( 猴面包树 ).
The idea of the herd( 兽群 ) of elephants made the little prince laugh.
“We would have to put them one on top of the other,” he said.
But he made a wise comment:
“Before they grow so big, the baobabs( 猴面包树 ) start out by being little.”
“That is strictly correct,” I said. “But why do you want the sheep to eat the little baobabs( 猴面包树 )?”
He answered me at once, “Oh, come, come!”, as if he were speaking of something that was self-evident( 显而易见的 ).
And I was obliged to( 不得不 ) make a great mental effort to solve this problem, without any assistance( 援助 ).
Indeed, as I learned, there were on the planet where the little prince lived—as on all planets—good plants and bad plants.
In consequence, there were good seeds from good plants, and bad seeds from bad plants.
But seeds are invisible( 看不见的 ).
They sleep deep in the heart of the earth’s darkness, until someone among them is seized with the desire to awaken.
Then this little seed will stretch( 伸长 ) itself and begin—timidly( 腼腆地 ) at first—to push a charming( 可爱的 ) little sprig( 枝丫 ) inoffensively upward toward the sun.
If it is only a sprout( 嫩芽 ) of radish( 小萝卜 ) or the sprig( 枝丫 ) of a rosebush( 玫瑰丛 ), one would let it grow wherever it might wish.
But when it is a bad plant, one must destroy it as soon as possible, the very first instant that one recognizes it.
Now there were some terrible seeds on the planet that was the home of the little prince; and these were the seeds of the baobab( 猴面包树 ).
The soil of that planet was infested with( 到处都是... ) them.
A baobab( 猴面包树 ) is something you will never, never be able to get rid of( 摆脱 ) if you attend to( 处理 ) it too late.
It spreads over the entire planet.
It bores clear through( 贯穿 ) it with its roots.
And if the planet is too small, and the baobabs( 猴面包树 ) are too many, they split( 使裂开 ) it in pieces . . .
“It is a question of discipline( 纪律 ),” the little prince said to me later on.
“When you’ve finished your own toilet in the morning, then it is time to attend to( 处理 ) the toilet of your planet, just so, with the greatest care.
You must see to it that you pull up regularly all the baobabs( 猴面包树 ), at the very first moment
when they can be distinguished( 区分 ) from the rosebushes( 玫瑰丛 ) which they resemble( 相似 ) so closely in their earliest youth.
It is very tedious( 单调乏味的 ) work,” the little prince added, “but very easy.”
And one day he said to me:
“You ought to make a beautiful drawing, so that the children where you live can see exactly how all this is.
That would be very useful to them if they were to travel someday. Sometimes,” he added, “there is no harm in putting off a piece of work until another day.
But when it is a matter of baobabs( 猴面包树 ), that always means a catastrophe( 大灾害 ).
I knew a planet that was inhabited( 居住 ) by a lazy man. He neglected( 忽视 ) three little bushes . . .”
So, as the little prince described it to me, I made a drawing of that planet.
I do not much like to take the tone( 语气 ) of a moralist( 道德家 ).
But the danger of the baobabs( 猴面包树 ) is so little understood, and such considerable risks would be run by anyone who might get lost on an asteroid( 小行星 ),
that for once I am breaking through my reserve.
“Children,” I say plainly, “watch out for the baobabs( 猴面包树 )!”
My friends, like myself, have been skirting( 位于...的边缘 ) this danger for a long time, without ever knowing it;
and so it is for them that I have worked so hard over this drawing.
The lesson which I pass on by this means is worth all the trouble it has cost me.
Perhaps you will ask me, “Why are there no other drawing in this book as magnificent( 令人惊叹的 ) and impressive as this drawing of the baobabs( 猴面包树 )?”
The reply is simple.
I have tried.
But with the others I have not been successful.
When I made the drawing of the baobabs( 猴面包树 ) I was carried beyond myself by the inspiring( 有激励作用的 ) force of urgent( 急迫的 ) necessity.
Oh, little prince!
Bit by bit( 逐渐地 ) I came to understand the secrets of your sad little life . . .
For a long time you had found your only entertainment( 娱乐方式 ) in the quiet pleasure of looking at the sunset.
I learned that new detail( 细节 ) on the morning of the fourth day, when you said to me:
“I am very fond of( 喜爱 ) sunsets. Come, let us go look at a sunset now.”
“But we must wait,” I said.
“Wait? For what?”
“For the sunset. We must wait until it is time.”
At first you seemed to be very much surprised. And then you laughed to yourself.
You said to me:
“I am always thinking that I am at home!”
Just so.
Everybody knows that when it is noon in the United States, the sun is setting over France.
If you could fly to France in one minute, you could go straight into the sunset, right from noon.
Unfortunately, France is too far away for that.
But on your tiny planet, my little prince, all you need do is move your chair a few steps.
You can see the day end and the twilight( 黄昏 ) falling whenever you like . . .
“One day,” you said to me, “I saw the sunset forty-four times!”
And a little later you added:
“You know—one loves the sunset, when one is so sad . . .”
“Were you so sad, then?” I asked, “on the day of the forty-four sunsets?”
But the little prince made no reply.

article_info.previous: 在昨天的故事中，“我”终于知道了小王子来自何方，那是一颗由一位土耳其天文学家发现的很小的行星，并且“我”很清楚这颗星球的发现过程。
article_info.share_words: “The proof that the little prince existed is that he was charming, that he laughed, and that he was looking for a sheep. If anybody wants a sheep, that is a proof that he exists.”

question.cn: “我”给小王子画的肖像画怎么样？
question.en: How were "my" portraits of the little prince?

options.en: They were all true to life.

analysis: 原文提到：I shall certainly try to make my portraits as true to life as possible...But I am not at all sure of success...In certain more important details I shall make mistakes, also. 所以答案为C。

question.cn: 根据“我”的话语，这只羊吃什么？
question.en: According to "my" words, what did the sheep eat?

analysis: 原文提到：“It is true, isn’t it, that sheep eat little bushes?” “Yes, that is true.” 所以答案为A。

question.cn: 为什么小王子想让羊吃猴面包树？
question.en: Why did the little prince want the sheep to eat the baobabs?

options.cn: 因为在小王子的行星上，猴面包树很危险。
options.en: Because baobabs are dangerous on the little prince’s planet.

options.cn: 因为大象不吃猴面包树。

analysis: 原文提到：And if the planet is too small, and the baobabs are too many, they split it in pieces。因为小王子的行星很小，但是猴面包树却很多，它们会对行星造成威胁，所以答案选A。

question.cn: 小王子在他行星上的娱乐方式是什么？
question.en: What was the little prince’s entertainment on his planet?

analysis: 原文提到：For a long time you had found your only entertainment in the quiet pleasure of looking at the sunset. 所以答案选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第3天
